Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptation Across Latitude and Altitude: Genomics, Morphology, and Physiology of Montane Bumble Bees
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the ways in which species cope with environmental variability is of fundamental importance in evolutionary biology and has implications for predicting organismal responses to global change. Adaptation to environmental variation can be inferred by examining physiological and genetic variation across a broad range of environments, but spatial, physical, or environmental barriers to dispersal also influence the distribution of such characteristics. Species that occur across latitude and elevation gradients present unique advantages for teasing apart how different evolutionary forces interact with environmental variation to shape morphological, physiological, and genetic diversity. This project will investigate physiological and genomic responses to environmental variation in montane bumblebees. In light of evidence for pollinator declines and widespread expectations for future environmental changes, results will simultaneously address questions about evolutionary adaptation, and yield advancements to predict impacts of climate and migration barriers on a key pollinator group.

This project will combine measurements of physiology and morphology with next-generation genomic DNA sequencing in wild and laboratory reared populations sampled across California, Oregon, and Washington to produce several lines of evidence for adaptation to abiotic gradients. Questions to be addressed include: (1) Does variation in body and wing morphology across latitude and altitude match predicted responses to pressures on thermoregulation and flight? (2) Do latitude and altitude drive genetic change through dispersal limitations, or do genes exhibit signatures of environmental adaptation? (3) Do laboratory bees reared from latitude and altitude extremes exhibit differences in flight physiology and gene expression regulation in laboratory flight challenges?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the ways in which species cope with environmental variability is of fundamental importance in ecology and evolutionary biology and has implications for predicting organismal responses to global change. Adaptation to environmental variation can be inferred by examining physiological and genetic variation across a broad range of environments, but spatial, physical, or environmental barriers to dispersal also influence the distribution of such characteristics. Species that occur across latitude and elevation gradients present unique advantages for teasing apart how different evolutionary forces interact with environmental variation to shape morphological, physiological, and genetic diversity. This project investigated physiological and genomic responses to environmental variation in montane bumblebees across the Sierra and Cascade mountain ranges from southern California through northern Washington, USA.

The first major result from this grant is that montane landscapes challenge dispersal and reduce population sizes in bumble bees in complex ways. Genetic data demonstrate that species occupying primarily high elevation sites are especially susceptible to habitat fragmentation from intervening regions of low habitat suitability, while species that can survive at low elevations show much greater genetic connectivity even when populations also occupy high elevation habitat. These results have important implications for pollinators, in that species are predicted to shift upslope in coming years, and if this occurs our data demonstrate that all species may be susceptible to increased population fragmentation.

The second main result examines adaptation of bees to climate across montane landscapes. Bumble bees are well known as thermoregulatory marvels, and can employ different methods to generate, retain, and dissipate heat. We have used genomic data to untangle ways in which populations may adapt to their local environments to tolerate variation in temperature. In particular, we see that genes associated with muscles, motor neurons, and ion balance are likely to be important sources of adaptation to temperature variation.

For the third major result we focused on thermal tolerance using laboratory reared bumble bee colonies from low and high latitudes and altitudes to examine populations that experience different temperatures. Physiological experiments show that bumble bee thermal tolerance is directly related to the environment from which they were sampled. Analysis of gene expression shows that genomic responses to temperature stress are similarly population-specific. Together with adaptation results, these experimental data provide important clues into the ways in which bumble bees are able to tolerate different temperatures across their geographic ranges.

Three graduate students, a postdoc, and more than ten undergraduate researchers have received training in pollinator biology and diversity, molecular biology and genomics, and computational biology. The project also resulted in the development of an engaging ?edutainment? video game module that employs motion capture to teach users about bumble bee flight in challenging mountainous landscapes, an interactive sculptural exhibit exploring our fascination with and sometimes fear of bees and a new Guide to the Native Bees of Wyoming, and new techniques for rearing bumblebees for managed pollination. Thus, in addition to advances in basic knowledge about bumble bee ecology and evolution in mountainous regions, this project has also generated significant broader impacts relating to pollinator conservation and management.
